Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Reconstructing the Origins of the Colorado River: An Integrative Study of the Miocene-Pliocene Bouse Formation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Despite nearly a century of study, the conditions that controlled initiation of the mighty Colorado River remain poorly understood and vigorously debated. This project seeks to reconstruct the origins of the Colorado River through multidisciplinary study of the Bouse Formation, a complex sedimentary deposit that accumulated in the lower reaches of the valley during river initiation between ~ 6.0 and 4.5 million years ago. The study benefits from collaborations among university professors and students, state and federal agency scientists, a county museum paleontologist, and a local high school teacher.

The PI's will use integrated datasets to determine if the Bouse Formation formed in a brackish marine estuary or a large inland lake isolated from the ocean, a key distinction for understanding the origins of the river. This study also explores when and how waters of the Colorado River first reached the sea. Hypotheses will be tested through study of stratigraphic architecture, sedimentology, carbonate geochemistry (including C, O, Sr, and S isotopes), and geochronology. Hypothesis tests emphasize cross-correlation of radiogenic and stable isotope data with major and trace-element chemistry in a precise stratigraphic and structural framework. The PI's will run two workshops: one to engage a broad community of geoscientists, and one to plan a future scientific drilling proposal.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This collaborative project engaged P.I.s and student researchers from three state universities, USGS, Arizona Geological Survey, Colorado River Indian Tribes, and local school teachers in a study of the birth and early evolution of the Colorado River. Field work for this study included detailed geologic mapping, measuring stratigraphic sections, process sedimentology, collection of samples in precise stratigraphic context, and paleontologic study of microfossils and calcareous algae in the southern Bouse Formation. We also conducted a synthesis of regional stratigraphy, sedimentology, and paleontology from deposits of the southern Bouse Formation and similar age deposits in the western Salton Trough, to interpret the processes and events that controlled the birth and early evolution of the Colorado River. In the final year of the project we co-convened a community workshop to start planning for a future drilling project to study the Bouse Formation in the subsurface. Some highlights of this study are summarized below.

The southern Bouse Formation can be divided into three laterally persistent members: basal carbonate, siliciclastic, and upper bioclastic members. The basal carbonate member contains abundant sedimentary structures, microfossils, trace fossils, microscopic textures, and facies associations that provide evidence for sedimentation in a tidal depositional system. These deposits accumulated in a tide-dominated marine embayment during a rise of relative sea level due to tecotnic subsidence between ~6.3 and 5.4 Ma, prior to arrival of the Colorado River. The upper facies of the basal carbonate member is fine-grained marl that records deposition in deeper water after a prolonged rise in relative sea level. The abrupt transition from subtidal marl to green claystone of the siliciclastic member records initial rapid influx of river water and its distal clay wash load into the marine basin at about 5.4?5.3 Ma. This was followed by rapid southward progradation of the Colorado River delta into the study area, establishment of the earliest through flowing river as recorded in thick cross bedded sandstone deposits near Cibola, Ariz., and deposition of river-derived turbidites at the north end of the paleo-Gulf of California ~5.3?5.1 Ma. Early delta progradation was followed by regional shutdown of river sand output between ~5.1 and 4.8 Ma that resulted in deposition of marine clay in the Salton Trough, retreat of the delta, and reflooding of the lower river valley by shallow marine waters that deposited the Bouse upper bioclastic member. Evidence for shallow marine conditions in the lower Colorado River valley during the re-flooding stage includes: (1) well sorted bioclastic carbonate with abundant mollusk fossils, burrows, and wave-ripple lamination; (2) sandy and pebbly bioclastic carbonate with flat-based wave-formed gravelly ripples (wavelengths 0.5-3.0 meters); and (3) distinctive upward-branching segmented marine coralline red algae closely associated with echinoderm spines, whole articulated barnacles, shallow marine foraminifers Ammonia beccarii, and marine bivalves Macoma and Mulinia. Resumption of sediment discharge at ~4.8 Ma drove rapid progradation of voluminous fluvial deltaic deposits back down the river valley into the northern Gulf of California.

The southern Bouse Formation also contains a stratigraphic record of transtensional faulting and fault-related folding within a fault belt known as the Eastern California Shear Zone (ECSZ). Our data reveal diagnostic stratal wedge geometries that record a history of syn-depositional tilting and fault-controlled subsidence in response to growth of normal and oblique-slip faults around the basin margins. Some faults formed at depth and propagated to the surface during Bouse deposition, while others evolved as blind faults that remain buried in the subsurface today. Fault growth resulted in slow subsidence by sagging in a series of regional depocenters that currently reside beneath the modern floodplain of the Colorado River. These results provide new constraints on the time-space evolution of the ECSZ, and support prior suggestions that regional subsidence in a fault-bounded tectonic lowland controlled latest Miocene marine inundation followed by integration of the Colorado River into the northern Gulf of California at ca. 5 Ma.
